candidates.title: Did Marla Maples Die in a Plane Crash?
candidates.content:
Claim:
President Trump's second wife, Marla Maples, died in a plane crash in April 2017.
Rating:
False
About this rating
On 17 April 2017, fake news site True Trumpers published a page containing only the clickbait headline "Just In: Trumps Ex-Wife Marla Maples Died After Airline Accident!" and a photograph of what appeared to be the wreckage of a crashed plane:
There is no truth to the sensational headline, a claim which would have made worldwide news if it were accurate; indeed, the image used here is actually from July 1997, when a Federal Express plane crashed and burned during a landing at Newark International Airport. (Despite the dramatic image, only minor injuries were reported.)
candidates.description: Reports that President Trump's ex-wife Marla Maples died in an airline accident are fake news that reused 1997 images of a downed cargo jet.

result.explanation: The news caption is rated as false by Snopes.  Snopes directly refutes the claim that Marla Maples died in a plane crash in April 2017, citing it as fake news that used an unrelated image from a 1997 plane crash.  The Snopes article explicitly states that the claim is false and explains that the image used to support the false claim was from a 1997 incident.
result.supporting_points: Source 1: Snopes fact-check explicitly labels the claim as false and details how a fake news site used an unrelated image from a 1997 plane crash to support the false narrative. The Snopes article clearly states that the claim is untrue.

final_result.explanation: Both internal and external checks strongly indicate that the original caption is out of context. The internal check has a confidence score of 0 and correctly identifies that the image depicts Marla Maples, but the caption falsely claims she died in a plane crash in April 2017.  This is further corroborated by the external check which provides a confidence score of 10, citing Snopes, a reputable fact-checking website. Snopes explicitly debunks this claim, confirming that Marla Maples is still alive and that the claim originated from fake news sources which misused an unrelated image from a 1997 plane crash.  There is no conflict between the internal and external assessments; both point to the caption being factually incorrect and out of context. The high confidence score of 10 reflects the strong evidence from both the internal analysis and the external verification through Snopes.  The image is clearly of Marla Maples, and widely available information confirms she is alive, directly contradicting the caption's assertion.  There is no ambiguity or uncertainty in this case. The evidence consistently shows that the caption is entirely false and unrelated to the image.
final_result.validation_summary: Both internal and external validation methods strongly support that the caption is out of context. The internal analysis identifies the image subject correctly but refutes the caption's false death claim.  External verification using Snopes provides definitive proof of the claim's falsity.
